title: Religious Organizations should be taxed just like everything else.

author: DarkBrandon46
text: As a religious man, I agree. If religious organization are no longer tax exempt they will no longer have to follow the requirement in 501(c)(3) that roadblocks them from endorsing political campaigns. We will become just like private businesses and we can now fund any political campaign we want with no roadblocks and can now have churches everywhere telling it's members to support the candidate God wants you to pick. Are you still on board now? Lol

author: thiswaynotthatway
text:
That's fine, churches aren't held to those requirements at the moment anyway. Many churches make a point of daring the tax office to come after them and the FFRF has SUCCESSFULLY sued the IRS to do their job but still no action.

There shouldn't be a single mention of religion in the law other than to forbid discrimination on the basis thereof. Churches should get no special exemptions for tax, or any other law or regulation. As it is religious organisations are a law unto themselves, being the substandard choice for nearly everything due to swathing exemptions from safety, employee protection, and anything else you can think of. In some places if you drive a bus for the local rleigious institution you don't need to meet the otherwise necessary licensing requirements.

author: DarkBrandon46
text: Churches are held to those requirements. If you report it, the IRS does follow up on it. Also, when FFRF sued the IRS over politicking the case was dismissed.

author: thiswaynotthatway
text:
Name me a single church that has faced enforcement on this issue.

The FFRF/IRS case was voluntarily dismissed by the FFRF after a deal was made with the IRS to do their job... which they since haven't done.

More than that, the Trump administration specifically crafted an Executive Order that the Johnson amendment NOT be enforced against religious organisations, and only secular 501(c)(3)s that had to earn their privelege rather than just ticking the
imma church" box have to abide by it. [source](https://www.natlawreview.com/article/president-trump-signs-johnson-amendment-executive-order-limiting-treasury-s-actions)

Churches have no oversight, which is why they are hive of corruption and politicking, damaging to Democracy. Religious organisations are the **last** ones we should consider giving special exemptions for anything to, seein as they are by default a bunch of con artists selling something that doesn't exist for their own purposes.

There is absolutely no oversight for church 501c3 status. They don't have to go through the same oversight or requirements when setting up, they don't have the ongoing oversight and reporting requirements, and they don't have to refrain from politicking because the laws against it aren't enforced against them.

author: DarkBrandon46
text:
https://www.thecentersquare.com/texas/irs-denies-christian-nonprofit-tax-exemption-saying-biblical-values-are-republican/article_c0cbd742-cfb5-11eb-bcf6-4b01e4037740.html

We also had that crazy pastor recently who was calling Dems demons and tiktok mass reported him to the IRS and he went on to revoke his own tax exemption status on his own terms before they could revoke it. He's now calling 501s "communism" which is funny because he had no problem with "communism" until he was getting reported to the IRS.

That case you're talking about was dismissed because the IRS proved they were doing their job and working on cases the FFRF reported prior to even being taken it court.

>The executive order limits enforcement of the Johnson Amendment or any other adverse action against any individual or religious organization for speaking about moral or political issues from a religious perspective.

So basically nothing changes. This is the status quo. The treasury department should not take action against a religious organization if the organization hasn't engaged in political campaign intervention. This is a nothing burger. It was just a political stunt by Trump to make his evangelical supporters believe he got rid of the Johnson amendment.

It's difficult to prove without reasonable doubt that a church is participating in political campaign intervention. Their job is not easy. There's a fine line between this and free speech the IRS has to walk. What many consider a violation is technically not. These things rarely happen. But they do happen. The IRS does follow up on tips and they do take them seriously. IRS agents arent cackling their fingers and laughing like evil villains blatantly allowing churchs to violate the terms like you're painting them to be. They are human beings trying to do the best they can like many of us are. Let's leave the systematic conspiracies to the kooks.

author: thiswaynotthatway
text:
So your only examples are 1, not a church, and 2, a guy who didn't have his 501c3 status revoked but **claims** to have given it up himself. Where is the enforcement against any single church? Even the Pulpit Freedom Sunday churches who made a show of breaking the law kept their 501c3 status. You're mad or blind if you think these laws actually apply, they **clearly** do not.


> It's difficult to prove without reasonable doubt that a church is participating in political campaign intervention.

It's not when they fucking record themselves doing it and broadcast it.

[Here](https://www.propublica.org/article/irs-church-nonprofit-endorsements-johnson-amendment) is a recent article on churches flouting the Johnson Amendment restrictions to no repurcussions.


There are effectively no restrictions on churches, which is why these naturally corruption attracting organisations are flat out being forced into being even more corrupt.

author: Derrythe
text:
To be fair, the rule that churches can't 'preach politics' isn't enforced.  The IRS doesn't actually go after any of the churches who break that rule.

I'm also not on board with political donations at all.  I think citizens united went the wrong way, saying that organizations are people and so they should be able to donate to political campaigns.  I don't think people should be able to either.  Politicians, campaigns, and parties should be entirely publicly funded and should be illegal for anyone to give any donations or excessive gifts to a party, campaign, of politician.

author: DarkBrandon46
text: It is enforced. They do actually go after churches who break that rule.
